properties.sfomuseum:description: Interviewed on September 20 and October 12, 2021The interview describes the life and career of Captain Julie E. Clark, who was the first female pilot hired by Golden West Airlines in 1976 and one of the first two female pilots hired by Hughes Airwest in 1977, then remained through the mergers with first Republic Airlines in 1980 and Northwest Airlines in 2004, where she remained until her retirement; she was also an accomplished aerobatic pilot who founded her own airshow company, Julie Clark’s American Aerobatics, in 1980; early life and family history with aviation, including her father’s career with Pacific Airlines and his death at the hands of a passenger in 1964; motivation to become a pilot; education and training; work prior to the airlines as a Naval flight instructor and a cargo and charter pilot; hiring at Golden West; decision to go to Hughes Airwest; hiring process, her training, her roles and tasks as a first officer on the Douglas DC-9 flying out of San Francisco International Airport (SFO); culture at Hughes; merger into Republic Airlines; progression to Captain; flying the Convair 580 based in Minneapolis; incident on the DC-9 / McDonnell-Douglas MD-80 in Las Vegas; culture at Republic; merger with Northwest Airlines and challenges; role of a captain, her experiences with seniority, and the value of crew resource management; work with Northwest, transition to the Airbus A320, the experience of commuting to Minneapolis base, and retirement flight; experiences as a female pilot; effect of her career on her family life; work as an aerobatic pilot and airshow career; acquisition of Beechcraft T-24 Mentor at auction, the restoration process; introduction to airshow flying; balancing airshow career with that of an airline flight officer; finding and keeping sponsors; most recent choreographed routine and the airshows flown, with details about the work there; awards earned, organization memberships including ISA+21, the 99s, and Women in Aviation; experiences of mentorship; uniforms worn with the airlines.
